Question: A teacher makes the following statement to her class: 'If you get an A on the final exam, then you will pass the course.' Which of the following situations would prove that the teacher's statement is false?

A) A student gets an A on the final exam and passes the course.
B) A student gets an A on the final exam and fails the course.
C) A student does not get an A on the final exam and passes the course.
D) A student does not get an A on the final exam and fails the course.

Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out which situation would prove that the teacher's statement is false.
The teacher said, "If you get an A on the final exam, then you will pass the course." Hmm, that sounds like a conditional statement.
In logic, that's like saying if P then Q, where P is getting an A and Q is passing the course.
Alright, so to disprove this statement, I need to find a situation where P is true but Q is false.
Because in logic, the only way the statement "If P, then Q" is false is when P is true and Q is false.
That's called a counterexample.
Let me go through each option one by one.
Option A: A student gets an A and passes.
Well, that fits the teacher's statement.
If you get an A, you pass.
So this doesn't disprove it; it actually supports the statement.
Option B: A student gets an A and fails.
Wait, that seems contradictory.
If you get an A, according to the teacher, you should pass.
But here, the student got an A and failed.
That directly contradicts the teacher's statement.
So this would be a counterexample, proving the teacher's statement is false.
Option C: A student doesn't get an A and passes.
The teacher didn't say anything about what happens if you don't get an A.
She only made a promise about getting an A leading to passing.
So this doesn't affect the truth of her statement.
It's possible to pass without an A, but that's allowed in the teacher's statement.
Option D: A student doesn't get an A and fails.
Again, the teacher's statement doesn't cover this scenario.
She only said that getting an A means you'll pass.
She didn't say that not getting an A means you'll fail.
So this situation doesn't disprove her statement either.
So, putting it all together, the only situation that directly contradicts the teacher's statement is Option B.
If a student gets an A but fails, that means the teacher's "if A then pass" is not always true.

</think>

The teacher's statement is "If you get an A, then you will pass." To disprove this, we need a case where someone gets an A but doesn't pass.
That's exactly what happens in situation B.
**Answer:** B) A student gets an A on the final exam and fails the course.
